dialogue: You're good.
Do you have something for me?
Voluntary manslaughter, with a recommendation of 20 years - 15 to serve, followed by 5 on probation. Standard conditions.
Wow. That's a helluva deal.
I’ll even waive the recidivist statute, if he pleads before we strike the jury.
Oooooooooo.....
And admit to something he didn't do...?
Save that for the jury. Or better yet, plead your guy out and go back to your three-figure caseload.
My client wants a trial.
Then you're wasting my time. And your "client's."
Last chance.
The facts of the case are these: one year ago, on October twenty-fifth, James Sythe and his then-girlfriend Kendall Carter went drinking at Rowdy's Hideaway on Old Quarry Road.
Things got tense. They had a fight.
She stormed out of the bar. He followed her.
The fight escalated and quickly got out of control.
... This was par for the course. They'd argue, it was "over." Then they'd make up the next day when they both had calmed down. It was basically a game.
She was serious this time. She was DONE with him; and so she left and headed down the road on foot...
This was just another typical night of "drama", so James Sythe got in his car and drove home.
He flew into a violent rage and followed Kendall Carter down the road.
And then he killed her.
He beat her viciously, pushed her over a railing -- into the creek below -- and left her to die.
James Sythe didn't attack her and couldn't have pushed her. Because he wasn't there.
James Sythe took an innocent life!
...James Sythe is an innocent man!
Nice speech.
Thanks.
"Justice is truth in action?"
Professor Nielson.
I remember. You still believe it?
Of course.
Just as long as it doesn't get in the way of a win though, right?
If you have something to say, Eric. Say it.
You were his favorite student. And now you're a...
A what?
A politican.
Are you drunk?
Yeah.
C'mon. I'll give you a ride.
So she left and then what happened?
You saw him walk down Old Quarry Road?
... An innocent man who is shattered from losing the love of his life.
An eyewitness saw him at the crime scene AT the time of death.
In the middle of the night during a rainstorm. It could have been anyone.
When she broke up with him that night, and he realized she meant it, he snapped. And so he bludgeoned her.
No murder weapon was recovered.
The defendant's DNA was found all over the victim. No one else's.
Of course there was DNA. They were a couple!
Until they weren't.
James Sythe bravely took the stand and admitted some difficult truths.
It was a performance. Nothing more.
The one thing we can agree on is this: the person responsible for Kendall Carter's death deserves to face justice.
That person is James Sythe.
That person is still out there.
Find him guilty.
Find James Sythe not guilty.
There she is! This round's on you!
What I'm having is a great evening. Isn't this a lovely evening?
It should've been a two-hour verdict.
What can I tell you? They're taking their job seriously. I gave them a lot to think about.
I've got a mountain of evidence. You gave them smoke and mirrors.
Where there's smoke, there's fire.
I admire your optimism.
Look, here's the thing: You walk into court convinced of the guilt of the defendant. Me, I don't have any illusions about what I do.
Well, enjoy it while you can.
To the justice system. It ain't perfect but it's the best we've got.
Americano with Soy milk.
Close enough.
What?
"Our resources are already stretched so thin?" You are something.
What the hell is this about?
I need to see him.
Really? For what possible reason?
So he can look me in the eye and say he didn't do it.
So, I’m right. You have doubt.
I’m not sure.
You know something isn’t right here, hell, even the jury knows it.
Can you prove that's what happened?
Can you prove it didn’t.
Thanks. She sets it down as he looks around the office.
Well, you did it. Hope it was worth it.
Ale House later. You're buying.
